div.p: >> Hi, this is Joyce Farrell.

I want to talk about
using parallel arrays.
What are parallel arrays?

Well, parallel arrays occur
when you have two or more arrays

in memory, and they're parallel
when the data in each element

of one array logically
corresponds to the data

in the same relative
position in the second array.

For example, suppose
you have four employees

with different ID numbers, and
different names, and you want
to be able to write a program

where a user can
input the ID number
and output the correct name.

You would start by declaring an
array of ID numbers as follows:

numeric ID number -- four of
them -- and then list them.

In memory, the ID numbers
would look like this.

Then you declare
an array of names.

And in memory, they'd
look like this.

You'd need a few
other variables.

A numeric subscript used to
cycle through the array looking

for the correct ID
number, a user entry

where the user will
type in the ID number

that we're looking
for, and a found name,

where we're going to store the
correct name when we find it.

For right now, it's going
to say, "not found."

When you start the program,
the subscript is set to zero.
Then you input the user's entry.

Let's assume the
user types in 172.

You compare the subscript
to four

to make sure you've not gone
past the end of the array,

and the subscript is zero,
so it is less than four,

and then you compare the user's
entry, 172, with the ID number
at position zero, which is 121.

They're not equal, so we'll
end the if statement and wait

until later to show what
we do when they are equal.

Then add one to the subscript, so
it's one, and you reach the end
of the body of the loop.

You return to the top and
compare the subscript to four.

It's less, so you compare
the user's entry, 172,

with the ID number in
position one, which is 135.

They're not equal, so
the if statement ends,
and you add one more to sub.
So, sub is now two.

The loop is at the end, and
you compare the subscript
to four again.

You're still within range,
so the loop continues.

When you compare the user
entry, 172, with ID number two,
this time they're equal.

So, in the foundName
you store the name

at position two in
the name array.

The arrays are parallel because
the ID number at position two

in one array corresponds
to the name

and position two
in the other array.

Then you end the if statement,
add one to the subscript,

reach the bottom of the loop,
compare the subscript to four.

It is still less, so
you compare 189 and 172.

They're not equal, so
the if statement ends.
You increase the subscript.

It's the end of the
while loop.

Now when you compare sub to
four, it's not less than four,
so the loop is over.

You continue then to output
the ID number, the user entry,

which is 172, and the
found name that goes
with the user entry, Carl.

You've successfully
found the right name

with the ID number
that was entered.

Now, if the array had had 100
elements instead of only four,

the loop would have
continued for a long while
after you found ID number 172.

You can make the loop a little
more efficient by exiting

as soon as you find
the correct name,
so let's start over.

Let's make the loop efficient by
changing the while statement

to not only to compare the sub
to four, but also to compare the
found name to not found.

While it still says "not
found," you want to keep going.

Let's wipe everything
out and start over.

Wipe out the subscript
and the user entry,

and set foundName
back to "not found."

This time when the code
starts, you can set sub to zero.

Let's say the user enters
121. Compare sub to four,
it is less than four,
and compare foundName to not found.

It is not found,
so enter the loop

and compare the user
entry to ID number zero.

121 is 121, so you
can take foundName
and set it to name[0]
foundName becomes Ann.

That's the end of the if
statement, and sub becomes one.

That's the end of the loop,
so you go back to the top.

sub is less than four, but
foundName is not "not found."
foundName is now Ann,
so the while loop is over.

It's not going to
execute anymore.

You can output the ID number,
121, and the foundName, Ann,

by getting out of
the loop early when

foundName no longer
was "not found."
You saved a lot of time.
[ Silence ]
Thanks for watching.
